original_data.question: A 60-year-old man is referred to a dermatologist by his family physician for management of a rare case of dermatitis that has not responded to standard therapy with corticosteroids. The patient’s medical history is unremarkable, and he is currently working reduced hours at his job as an accountant. Physical examination reveals confluent scaly patches, plaques, and generalized erythroderma along the torso and lower extremities (see image). There is also a solid skin lesion with a diameter greater than 1 cm. The dermatologist suspects a malignancy and orders a biopsy. Which of the following is the most accurate description of this condition?

options.B: Tumor arising from the folliculosebaceous–apocrine germ
options.C: Tumor arising from cutaneous T cells

model_response:
The patient has a malignant tumor of epidermal keratinocytes, also known as squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). This is the second most common form of skin cancer, and it is strongly associated with cumulative exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation. The incidence of SCC also increases with age, and it is more common in men than in women. The most common predisposing factor is exposure to UV radiation, especially in fair-skinned people. Other predisposing factors include chemical carcinogens (arsenicals, tar, and oils), chronic inflammation, and human papilloma virus (HPV) infection. The diagnosis is established by biopsy, and the prognosis depends on the tumor’s depth of invasion. Superficial SCCs are confined to the epidermis and have an excellent prognosis. In contrast, invasive SCCs extend into the dermis and have a much poorer prognosis.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Those physicians who have completed the education requirements specified by the American Academy of Family Physicians.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
Any inflammation of the skin.
The minimum acceptable patient care, based on statutes, court decisions, policies, or professional guidelines.
HORMONES produced by the ADRENAL CORTEX, including both steroid and peptide hormones. The major hormones produced are HYDROCORTISONE and ALDOSTERONE.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Shedding of the outer layer of skin or mucosal tissue.

The widespread involvement of the skin by a scaly, erythematous dermatitis occurring either as a secondary or reactive process to an underlying cutaneous disorder (e.g., atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, etc.), or as a primary or idiopathic disease. It is often associated with the loss of hair and nails, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles, and pruritus. (From Dorland, 27th ed)
The central part of the body to which the neck and limbs are attached.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.
The state in which a substance has no tendency to flow under moderate stress; resists forces (such as compression) that tend to deform it; and retains a definite size and shape.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and connecting two points on the circumference.
Physicians who specialize in treating disorders of the skin.
Believed likely.

A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Description:Represents the HL7 content "domain" that supports orders - and "comprises the models, messages, and other artifacts that are needed to support messaging related to ordering basic healthcare services."UsageNote:V3 Specifications are published in a set of "domains", which contain interactions and related specifications for a single area of health care within which can be supported by a single, coherent set of interoperability specifications.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
